docs.abstract: A gap in the law means employers aren't required to accommodate pregnant women. A proposed bill in New York State would change that.
docs.snippet: A gap in the law means employers aren't required to accommodate pregnant women. A proposed bill in New York State would change that.

docs.lead_paragraph: Depending on your circumstances, being pregnant and needing just that little bit of extra accommodation at work - more bathroom breaks, a stool at the counter, a break from the requirement that all retail employees share in the lifting of boxes and climbing of ladders - could mean you're out of a job. Laws that ban discrimination against pregnant women in the workplace don't require that any special needs be accommodated, and the Americans With Disabilities Act, which would, doesn't apply to most pregnant women.
docs.abstract: A gap in the law means employers aren't required to accommodate pregnant women. A proposed bill in New York State would change that.
docs.snippet: A gap in the law means employers aren't required to accommodate pregnant women. A proposed bill in New York State would change that.

headline.main: A Wolf-Moose Standoff at Isle Royale

docs.abstract: When a moose stands down a pack of wolves, sometimes the wolves move on after a few minutes. Sometimes they remain for days.
docs.snippet: When a moose stands down a pack of wolves, sometimes the wolves move on after a few minutes. Sometimes they remain for days.

docs.lead_paragraph: John Vucetich, a wildlife ecologist from Michigan Technological University, leads the wolf-moose Winter Study at Isle Royale National Park.

headline.main: One Country, Two Systems? Not Lately

docs.abstract: A recent fight over spilled noodles on the Hong Kong subway has brought a nasty and escalating feud to the surface, with Hong Kongers accusing visitors from mainland China of everything from bad manners to high real estate prices to a lack of bed space at local maternity hospitals.
docs.snippet: A recent fight over spilled noodles on the Hong Kong subway has brought a nasty and escalating feud to the surface, with Hong Kongers accusing visitors from mainland China of everything from bad manners to high real estate prices to a lack of bed...

docs.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG - It pretty much started with a little girl from mainland China spilling some noodles onto the floor of a Hong Kong subway car.

docs.lead_paragraph: Thanks to a gap between discrimination laws and disability laws, it’s possible for a pregnant woman to be forced from her job.

headline.main: Pregnant, and Pushed Out of a Job
headline.print_headline: Pregnant, and Pushed Out of a Job

docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by lawyer Dina Bakst contends that legal gap between discrimination laws and disability laws is allowing some employers to force pregnant women out of jobs they are perfectly capable of performing; expresses support for legislation introduced by New York State lawmakers Liz Krueger and Aileen Gunther that would require employers to provide reasonable accommodations for pregnant women to continue at their jobs.
docs.snippet: Thanks to a gap between discrimination laws and disability laws, it’s possible for a pregnant woman to be forced from her job.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Kunduz Province authorities say that a woman, 22, was strangled by her husband and mother-in-law three months after she gave birth to a third girl.

headline.seo: Afghan Kin Accused of Killing Wife for Not Bearing a Son
headline.main: Afghan Kin Are Accused of Killing Woman for Not Bearing a Son
headline.print_headline: Afghan Kin Are Accused of Killing Woman for Not Bearing a Son

docs.abstract: Kunduz Province authorities say a young Afghan woman was strangled to death by her husband and mother-in-law for giving birth to a third daughter, rather than a son; death underscores the low status of women in Afghanistan.
docs.snippet: The Kunduz Province authorities say that a woman, 22, was strangled by her husband and mother-in-law three months after she gave birth to a third girl.

byline.contributor: Jawad Sukhanyar contributed reporting from Kabul, and an Afghan employee of The New York Times from Kunduz, Afghanistan.

docs.lead_paragraph: Many Catholic colleges are pushing back against a ruling by the Obama administration that the new health care law requires insurance plans at Catholic institutions to cover birth control.

headline.seo: Law Fuels Contraception Controversy on Catholic Campuses
headline.main: Ruling on Contraception Draws Battle Lines at Catholic Colleges
headline.print_headline: Ruling on Contraception Draws Battle Lines at Catholic Colleges

docs.abstract: Many Catholic colleges are pushing back against ruling by the Obama administration that the new health care law requires insurance plans at Catholic institutions to cover birth control; Catholic Church considers it morally wrong to prevent contraception by any artificial means; rule has now run headlong into a dispute over values as Republican presidential contenders compete for the most conservative voters (Series: Political Science).
docs.snippet: Many Catholic colleges are pushing back against a ruling by the Obama administration that the new health care law requires insurance plans at Catholic institutions to cover birth control.
